courses.title: Biology of SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19
courses.description: In-depth analysis of the COVID-19 pandemic including the following: molecular analysis of the causative agent SARS-CoV-2, clinical courses and epidemiology of the disease, population prevention and treatment of COVID-19, modeling and international health regulations regarding the pandemic, and comparisons of how different countries have addressed the pandemic.

courses.title: HIV and AIDS
courses.description: A comprehensive overview of the current AIDS pandemic ranging from molecular and biomedical aspects to societal and psychological aspects. Molecular biology of HIV, the immune system's response, diagnosis, prevention, treatment, and social implications are discussed.

courses.title: General Microbiology
courses.description: Morphology of microorganisms; growth; environmental and physiological types; physical and chemical control; taxonomy; viruses; genetics of bacteria; practical applications, including medical, water, soil, and food microbiology.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology
courses.description: Overview of the dynamic relationships between human hosts and pathogenic microbes. Topics include the human immune system, antimicrobial therapy, pathogenic bacteria, viruses, and pathogenic eukaryotic species.

courses.title: Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Regulation of gene expression in prokaryote explored through the use of recombinant DNA technologies.

courses.title: Global Infectious Diseases: Studies in Science and Society
courses.description: In this course we will examine microbiology, epidemiology, health management, and social impacts of several major infectious diseases from historical and global perspectives. Topics include influenza, HIV/AIDS, cholera, tuberculosis, malaria, and syphilis as well as others.

courses.title: Paraprofessional in Special Education Classroom
courses.description: Worked as a paraprofessional in a special education classroom with students ranging from kindergarten through fifth grade.

courses.title: Modern Evolutionary Theory
courses.description: This course will explore the history of evolutionary theory, review scientific evidence for evolution—particularly focusing upon the explosion of insights provided by Molecular Biology in the past 20 years, discuss social implications of the theory of evolution, and examine modern challenges like infectious diseases, genetic modification of crops, and climate changes that are particularly interesting from the perspective of evolution.

courses.title: Introduction to Public Health
courses.description: This course introduces students to Public Health as a population-based approach to preventing disease and prolonging human health through community action. An emphasis will be made on how public health knowledge plays a vital role in daily lives, and comparisons will be made between the public health systems of the U.S., other developed countries, and of developing countries.

courses.title: Global Infectious Diseases
courses.description: In this course we will look at the microbiology, epidemiology, management, and social impacts of six major human infectious diseases: influenza, HIV/AIDS, cholera, tuberculosis, malaria, and human helminthic infections.

courses.title: General Microbiology
courses.description: Structure, function, nutrition, physiology, and genetics of microbes and their application to immunology, pathology, microbial diversity, and environmental microbiology.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology
courses.description: Microbial pathogens and their relationships to disease.

courses.title: Molecular Genetics
courses.description: Introduction to prokaryotic and eukaryotic genome organization and gene expression, modern molecular techniques, experimental approaches, genome and gene analyses.

courses.title: Molecular Biology II
courses.description: Gene expression and regulation in prokaryotes and eukaryotes, including transcription, RNA processing, and translation; chromatin structure; DNA repair.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Anatomy and Physiology and Laboratory
Medical Microbiology for Second-Year Medical Students

courses.organization: U.S. Peace Corps, St. Vincent and the Grenadines
courses.title: General Science and Biology for Middle School and High School Students
